item.title: General Cubic Curve: Inflection Point and Symmetry
item.description: 1 Problem 2 Solution 3 Reference 1 Problem Problem 40, page 157 in Simmons (2016) Consider the general cubic equation \(y = a x^3 + b x^2 + c x + d\). Show that: It has one and only one point of inflection at \(I (\frac{-b}{3a}, k); k = \frac{2 b^3}{27 a^2} - \frac{bc}{3a} + d\), It has one maximum point and one minimum point if and only if \(b^2 - 3ac \gt 0\), The abscissa of \(I\) is the average of the abscissas of the maximum and minimum point, and The curve is symmetric with respect to \(I\) by Introducing a new \(X\)-axis and \(Y\)-axis such that \(X = x + \frac{b}{3a}\) and \(Y = y - k\) and making \(I\) as the origin of the \(XY\)-system, Showing that the equation of the curve in the \(XY\)-system is \(Y = aX \left(X^2 - \frac{b^2 - 3ac}{3 a^2} \right)\), and Showing that this transformed equation is symmetric with respect to \(I\).

item.title: Deriving the Quotient Rule from the Product Rule
item.description: 1 From Product to Quotient 1.1 Product Rule of Differentiation 1.2 Quotient Rule of Differentiation 1.3 Derive the Quotient Rule from the Product Rule 2 Problems 2.1 Extend the Product Rule and Prove 2.2 Tangent Lines Intersecting on a Curve 3 Reference 1 From Product to Quotient I have always had a hard time remembering the quotient rule for derivatives. I do not know how I remembered it while studying calculus, but today I learned from Simmons (2016) that I can derive it from the product rule.
